title: Shoppers say Tesco's bizarre chicken label blunder is an 'insult'
text:

There are very few people whose attention doesn't get quickly drawn to those bright yellow price signs in supermarkets.

As soon as you see one, you detect a bargain is about to come your way.

Even if the deal isn't actually keeping many pennies in your wallet or purse, nothing comes close to the feeling of getting a saving.

But Tesco's big offer was anything but after their brilliant price tag blunder.

Posting on a popular bargain-hunters Facebook group , Amanda Jane Cheese shared with fellow shoppers a picture of a chicken promotion she'd spotted at her local store in Stowmarket, Suffolk.

(Image: LightRocket via Getty Images)

The sign under the product stated how the British Extra Large Whole Chicken had been reduced from £4. Sounds decent enough.

But instead of being sold for cheaper, the store now appeared to be charging £4.25 for the chicken!

After Amanda shared the picture on Facebook the likes and comments quickly racked up, with shoppers ready to poke fun at the seemingly innocent pricing error.

"I love spotting these faux pas', it happens all the time in all supermarkets!" said one social media user.

Another joked: "omg...thats a bargain paying an extra 25p."

"That's not a bargain that's an insult," wrote somebody else.

A fourth quipped: "Wow someone's in trouble."

Tesco's website says the same product has been reduced down from £5 to £4.25 - stating a saving of 75p.

A spokesperson for Tesco told Manchester Evening News : "We’re sorry for the incorrect labelling on this product, it has now been updated in the store to show the correct reduction from £5 to £4.25."

Despite what many consumers believe, according to Citizens' Advice, if you take an item to the till and are told the price is a mistake, you don't have the right to buy the item at a lower price.

(Image: Getty Images)

You can still ask the store to honour the price, but they don't have to.

The same rule applies if you see an item advertised anywhere for a lower price than that on the price tag.

If you've already bought the item, and the shop's sold an item to you for less than they meant to, they're only legally allowed to ask for money back if you'd spoken about price and they ended up charging you much less.

If you realise you've paid more for an item than it was advertised for at the time you can ask the shop to refund the difference.
description: Those hoping to pick up a bargain in the Stowmarket store in Suffolk were surprised to find a poultry problem
